doc.sentence: Despite displaying similar affinities for XyG, reverse-genetic analysis reveals that SGBP-B is only required for the efficient capture of smaller oligosaccharides, whereas the presence of SGBP-A is more critical than its carbohydrate-binding ability for growth on XyG. Together, these data demonstrate that SGBP-A and SGBP-B play complementary, specialized roles in carbohydrate capture by B. ovatus and elaborate a model of how vegetable xyloglucans are accessed by the Bacteroidetes.

### EXAMPLES sentence	annotations SDS PAGE analysis of the purified Arabidopsis thaliana HAESA ectodomain (residues 20–620) obtained by secreted expression in insect cells.	<answer-list><answer entity="Arabidopsis thaliana" type="species"/><answer entity="20–620" type="residue_range"/></answer-list> Crystal structures of HAESA in complex with IDA reveal a hormone binding pocket that accommodates an active dodecamer peptide.	<answer-list><answer entity="Crystal structures" type="evidence"/><answer entity="in complex with" type="protein_state"/><answer entity="hormone binding pocket" type="site"/><answer entity="peptide" type="chemical"/></answer-list> Mechanistic insight into a peptide hormone signaling complex mediating floral organ abscission	<answer-list><answer entity="peptide hormone" type="protein_type"/></answer-list> Plants constantly renew during their life cycle and thus require to shed senescent and damaged organs.	<answer-list><answer entity="Plants" type="taxonomy_domain"/></answer-list> Santiago et al. used protein biochemistry, structural biology and genetics to uncover how the IDA hormone activates HAESA.	<answer-list><answer entity="protein biochemistry" type="experimental_method"/></answer-list> The HAESA LRR domain elutes as a monomer (black dotted line), as does the isolated SERK1 ectodomain (blue dotted line).	<answer-list><answer entity="monomer" type="oligomeric_state"/></answer-list> The IDA-HAESA and SERK1-HAESA complex interfaces are conserved among HAESA and HAESA-like proteins from different plant species.	<answer-list><answer entity="IDA-HAESA" type="complex_assembly"/></answer-list> The N- (residues 20–88) and C-terminal (residues 593–615) capping domains are shown in yellow, the central 21 LRR motifs are in blue and disulphide bonds are highlighted in green (in bonds representation). (C) Structure based sequence alignment of the 21 leucine-rich repeats in HAESA with the plant LRR consensus sequence shown for comparison.	<answer-list><answer entity="disulphide bonds" type="ptm"/></answer-list>
### INPUT Extract from the following text: Multiple sequence alignment coupled to a phylogenetic analysis reveals that certain enterobacteria exert evolutionary pressure on the lysine decarboxylase towards the cage-like assembly with RavA, implying that this complex may have an important function under particular stress conditions.

<answer entity="lysine decarboxylase" type="protein"/>
<answer entity="RavA" type="protein"/>
<answer entity="cage-like assembly" type="structure_element"/>
<answer entity="stress conditions" type="protein_state"/>
</answer-list>

doc.sentence: Plants can shed their leaves, flowers or other organs when they no longer need them. But how does a leaf or a flower know when to let go? A receptor protein called HAESA is found on the surface of the cells that surround a future break point on the plant. When its time to shed an organ, a hormone called IDA instructs HAESA to trigger the shedding process.
doc.annotations: <annotations><annotation entity='Plants' type='taxonomy_domain'></annotation><annotation entity='receptor protein' type='protein_type'></annotation><annotation entity='HAESA' type='protein'></annotation><annotation entity='hormone' type='chemical'></annotation><annotation entity='IDA' type='protein'></annotation><annotation entity='HAESA' type='protein'></annotation></annotations>

target: <annotations><annotation entity='Plants' type='taxonomy_domain'></annotation><annotation entity='receptor protein' type='protein_type'></annotation><annotation entity='HAESA' type='protein'></annotation><annotation entity='hormone' type='chemical'></annotation><annotation entity='IDA' type='protein'></annotation><annotation entity='HAESA' type='protein'></annotation></annotations>

doc.sentence: Polysaccharide utilization loci (PUL) within the genomes of resident human gut Bacteroidetes are central to the metabolism of the otherwise indigestible complex carbohydrates known as “dietary fiber.” However, functional characterization of PUL lags significantly behind sequencing efforts, which limits physiological understanding of the human-bacterial symbiosis.

doc.sentence: Structural analyses revealed that in contrast to the compact conformation of the dimeric YfiB alone, YfiBL43P adopts a stretched conformation allowing activated YfiB to penetrate the peptidoglycan (PG) layer and access YfiR. doc.sentence: The Bacteroidetes are dominant bacteria in the human gut that are responsible for the digestion of the complex polysaccharides that constitute “dietary fiber.” Although this symbiotic relationship has been appreciated for decades, little is currently known about how Bacteroidetes seek out and bind plant cell wall polysaccharides as a necessary first step in their metabolism.
